poem:
**Wales by Rail**

The tracks, like veins,  
stretch into the heart  
of a green dream,  
stone whispers of Shrewsbury,  
Aberystwyth's salt-kissed breeze,  
Porthmadog's dazzle.   
Steam curls in Ffestiniog,  
a smoky lace on slate peaks.  
Llandudno's distant call,  
an undulating return—  
a pulse of journeys  
where the sea kisses the rail,  
and time unfurls timelessly.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘A way to see more of Europe and help us slow down’: readers’ favourite rail journeys Winning tip: glorious north Wales circuit Starting from the border town of Shrewsbury, a spectacular multiday circuit of north Wales is possible: take the Cambrian Coast line through Aberystwyth, Barmouth, Porthmadog, then the gorgeous Ffestiniog Railway to Blaenau, where you can link back to Llandudno on the coast, and return to Shrewsbury (change at Llandudno Junction). There’s no shortage". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.

There’s no shortage
